learn.title: Learn
learn.disclaimer: Educational information only. This is not medical advice.

cycleBasics.title: Cycle basics: the main phases
cycleBasics.body: A typical cycle has phases. Menstrual: bleeding days. Follicular: energy may rise as the body prepares an egg. Ovulation: mid-cycle release of an egg. Luteal: the body prepares for the next period; PMS symptoms can appear. Every body is different.

trackingTips.title: Tracking tips that help
trackingTips.body: Log your period start date, optional end date, flow, and notes. Over time, patterns like average cycle length become clearer. If your cycle is irregular, tracking can still help you notice changes and talk to a clinician if needed.

commonSymptoms.title: Common symptoms
commonSymptoms.body: Cramps, bloating, headaches, fatigue, acne, and mood changes are common around your period. Rest, hydration, gentle movement, and heat can help some people. Severe symptoms are not something you should ignore.

whenToSeekCare.title: When to seek care
whenToSeekCare.body: Consider medical care if you have very heavy bleeding, fainting, severe pain, bleeding between periods, a sudden change in your cycle, or symptoms that disrupt daily life. For emergencies, seek urgent help right away.

fertileWindow.title: Fertile window basics
fertileWindow.body: Pregnancy is most likely in the days leading up to and including ovulation. Apps can estimate timing, but it’s not exact. If you’re trying to conceive or avoid pregnancy, consider using reliable methods and guidance from a clinician.

contraception.title: Contraception and planning
contraception.body: Different birth control options work in different ways (barrier methods, hormonal methods, IUDs, etc.). The best choice depends on your health and preferences. A clinician can help you choose what’s right for you.

sleepStress.title: Sleep and stress
sleepStress.body: Sleep and stress can affect mood, energy, and even cycle timing. Small routines—consistent sleep time, relaxing breath work, short walks—can support wellbeing during different cycle phases.

nutritionHydration.title: Nutrition and hydration
nutritionHydration.body: Regular meals, iron-rich foods, and enough water can support energy—especially during bleeding days. If you feel unusually weak or dizzy, consider checking in with a clinician.
